messageBody:
RE: [junit] cannot run testing with UI TestRunner?
Ok kids, let's all relax and think happy thoughts.  JUnit  is good.  Class loaders are your friends.  :)
 
The central issue here is:
 
JUnit's default class loader, let's call it ReloadingTestSuiteLoader, causes some people grief.  At the same time, it also saves some people grief.  Thus we have conflict in paradise.  The "quick fix" for those who experience grief is to say "-noloading".  If only we knew about that ahead of time, then we could avoid said grief.  For those who don't experience grief, there is no quick fix because, as the saying goes, it ain't broke.
 
To complicate the issue, the ReloadingTestSuiteLoader is a "magic feature".  A "magic feature" is a feature that you don't know is there - it does its magic silently.  They are often undocumented.  Unless someone told you it was there, you wouldn't necessarily know about it.  Magic features are your friends, except when they're not.  The unfortunate thing about this magic feature is that one often doesn't find out about until it causes them grief.  They learn about it the hard way.  It's great while it works, until it doesn't.
 
I feel that the "Q: I have grief. A: say -noloader." pattern appears on the discussion group frequently enough so as to be deemed "a problem".  Let's face it, the
ReloadingTestSuiteLoader is a mixed blessing.  It's not well documented, but once you know about it, it's cool.
 
What to do?  I say keep the feature (and all of its blessings), but don't make it the default behavior.  I.e., don't put people in a position that they have to find out the hard way.  Let's cause JUnit 3.6 to have a "-loader" flag that would enable the ReloadingTestSuiteLoader.  When that flag isn't given, then JUnit will use Java's default class loader.  Then, JUnit's default class loading behavior will be Java's default class loading behavior.  It's more intuitive that way anyway.
 
Discussion is warmly invited, as long as it's professional.  Flames to NLA0:
 
Cheers!
 
_chas_
